history.content:
I would say it will be a very tough summer for you considering how 61B is a project heavy course and cs70 is a problem-set type of course. I took CS70 over the summer by itself last year and I found myself with a relatively decent amount of spare time. I think if I had to add another class, I would not have chosen to add a cs course because then the workload becomes a lot more heavier.

I would say that you will definitely find yourself with little free time (so definitely no internships). My friend did CS70 and CS61B over the summer last year and he was essentially always either working on his project or his problem set for cs70

---

I did 61B and 70 the past summer.

I would definitely not recommend it. My schedule over the summer was:

9am, wake up. Grab food, head to Soda. 

11-2: 61BL lab. But rarely did I ever finish in 3 hours, so it was more like 11-3 or 11-4. 

2pm: 70 Lecture. I usually skipped lecture to work on 61BL. Learned the material by reading the notes. 

4-9: Either in Soda labs working on 61BL project, 61BL lab for that day, or at a homework party for CS70. Squeeze in dinner somewhere.

9-1am: Work on whatever is left over that day, or study for a midterm. Go to bed. 

Rinse and repeat. 

Weekends are spent studying; they are so valuable. Because you finally get two days of no new material. Instead, you can finish the 70 problem set, or finish the 61BL project. There's no time wasted, and definitely not a lot of time to relax. 

Week 3, I had 61BL and 70 back to back. Week 6, same deal. Week 8, we learned material for both courses up to Tuesday. Wednesday was CS70 (I took the alternate due to conflicting times), Friday was 61BL. During these three weeks, it was a lot of late night studying. And on off weeks, it was late night projects for 61BL. I did nothing but these two courses for 8 weeks. It burned me out, and I definitely was unhappy most of the summer. I ate unhealthily, and the only exercise I got was trekking to Soda from south side, walking to Morgan and back for 70 lecture, and then walking back home. 

So here's your fair warning.

I would say it will be a very tough summer for you considering how 61B is a project heavy course and cs70 is a problem-set type of course. I took CS70 over the summer by itself last year and I found myself with a relatively decent amount of spare time. I think if I had to add another class, I would not have chosen to add a cs course because then the workload becomes a lot more heavier.

I would say that you will definitely find yourself with little free time (so definitely no internships). My friend did CS70 and CS61B over the summer last year and he was essentially always either working on his project or his problem set for cs70

I would say it will be a very tough summer for you considering how 61B is a project heavy course and cs70 is a problem-set type of course.

I would say that you will definitely find yourself with little free time. My friend did CS70 and CS61B over the summer last year and he was essentially always either working on his project or his problem set for cs70

I would say it will be a very tough summer for you considering how 61B is a project heavy course and cs70 is a problem-set type of course. Moreover, I believe CS70 isn't being offered as well because there has not been an assigned instructor yet.

Of course if they do end up offering CS70 and you end up taking both, I would say that you will definitely find yourself with little free time. My friend did CS70 and CS61B over the summer last year and he was essentially always either working on his project or his problem set for cs70

children.subject:
I haven't taken either course over the summer, but I would add that for both of these courses, understanding the material (rather than just passing or getting a certain grade) is super important - moreso than with other classes that I've taken at Berkeley. 

61B is basically everything that you will ever get asked in interview questions for internships, and 70 gives you the background you need for other math and proof heavy classes. I personally didn't spend enough time really internalizing probability in 70, and now wish I did, because having a more intuitive understanding of what's going with probability would have helped me in 189. 

It probably is better to take just one of them, maybe with another light time commitment, and really digest and internalize the material, than it is to take both and get by with a certain grade without understanding the material in and out.

Just keep in mind that most of the summer sessions are 8 weeks when the regular semester is 16. The material is paced twice as fast. If both courses are in the same session, you won't be doing much else...
What about taking CS 70 and a humanities intro (reading-heavy) course at the same time?
Right now it seems that there's a time conflict between cs70 and cs61B while it is merely half hour of lecture. I was wondering if it is possible to override the schedule?

history.content: How doable would it be to take both 61B and 70 up here at berkeley in the summer? How is the workload of the two in the summer session?
history.subject: Workload of 61B AND 70 in the summer?
